This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE.
div.p: SUBSCRIPTIONS.-Alexandria, Cairo, and the Interior of Egypt (including delivery in Alexandria or postage to subscriber's address) P.T. 231½ per annum, P.T. 116 for six months, P.T. 80 for three months. To other countries in the Postal Union P.T. 273 (£2.16s.) per annum. Six months P.T. 136½ (£1.8s.), three months P.T. 92 (£0.19s.)
N.B.-Subscriptions commence from the 1st or 16th of any month.

ADVERTISEMENTS.-P.T. 4 per line. Minimum charge P.T. 20. Births, Marriages, or Deaths, not exceeding three lines, P.T. 20. Every additional line P.T. 10. Notices in news column P.T. 20 per line. Contracts entered into for standing advertisements.
SUBSCRIPTIONS and ADVERTISEMENTS are due in advance. P.O. Orders and Cheques to be made payable to the Editor and Manager, Rowland Snelling, Alexandria.
London Offices: 36, New Broad-street. E.C.
THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE" IS PRINTED ON PAPER MANUFACTURED AND SUPPLIED BY THE LONDON PAPER MILLS CO., LIMITED. (SALES OFFICE: 27, CANNON STREET, EC.)

div.head: The Egyptian Gazette
div.p: An English Daily Newspaper, Established in 1880.
Editor & Manager: R. Snelling.
Price: One Piastre Tariff.
SATURDAY, APRIL 15, 1905..

div.head: CAIRO DISTILLERIES.
div.p: A matter of great importance in many ways, and one demanding immediate attention, i dealt with in its various bearings, physical, moral, and political, by the writer of "Under the Mosquito Net" in our columns to day. The quotations he makes from a letter received from a correspondent in Cairo are alone suffi cient proof that such places as are described actually exist. How is it that up to the present time they have been allowed to flourish, and exert their pernicious influence unchecked and apparently unnoticed? The official answer would doubtless be to the effect that the Capitulations stand in the way of anything being done to suppress not only these practices, but many others that would be firmly taken in hand, if action, both by British and native officials, were not paralysed by these absurd and utterly out-of-date obligations. And although in view of what has taken place in regard to lotteries, some might incline to the opinion that in the matter of clearing away these stills it may also be found that "where there's a will there's a way," it is extremely difficult, as things are now, to suggest that way. All that appears possible is to lose no opportunity of showing up from time to time, and in every way possible, the existing state of affairs under the Capitulations. Nothing would help so greatly to secure their abolition,—or at least abrogation,-in matters on which they paralyse all efforts for the moral purification of this country, as the creation of a strong public opinion, determined to make a clean sweep of all these dens of iniquity that make our cities a by-word of reproach. We have already seen what can be effected in the various Courts of Europe by the persistent action of the National Vigilance Association in England, and there is no reason whatever why the British Government should not take very decided action to bring about a moral cleansing of Cairo. Our contributor suggests independent enquiry; we would prefer something more in the way of the Royal Commissions that are from time to time appointed in England to thoroughly investigate, and obtain the best and most reliable information on, the subjects they hove to report upon. Such an enquiry need not be a long one; these is plenty of evidence to be had for the asking, and if the matter were taken up at once and with energy, we might, ere another winter season brings us its visitors, have a cleaner Capital, and one offering them less temptation to the indulgence in vicious
courses.

div.head: ENGLISH COMMERCIAL TRAVELLERS.
div.p: In another column we publish an interesting statement from the report of the Austro-Hungarian Consul in Cairo on the subject of commercial travellers in Egypt, wherein he states that both in quality and quantity the Germans are far and away superior. In fact, he states that whereas 60 per cent. of travellers during the 1903-04 seson represented German houses, English firms were only represented by about four. How. these figures were obtained we do not know. The only possible source of information could be the Passport Offices at the ports. But such information could not be considered reliable, as many Englishmen combine business with pleasure and style themselves "tourists," although they utilise their trip to Egypt for the benefit of their business. We venture to differ from the statements contained in this Consular report, for all our evidence tends to show that now British commercial travellers are not only on the increase in Egypt, but are fully alive to the requirements of the market.

BRITISH CHAMBER OF COMMERCE.-We would call the attention of persons interested in Egyptian trade to the work of the British Chamber of Commerce of Egypt, whose office in Alexandria gives information as to standings, trade, &c., to its members, and whose monthly publication reviews our commerce. The annual subscription is £1 and all British traders should become members. Our London office, 36, New Broad-street E.C., acts as London agency to the Chanber,

div.head: THE WAR. RUSSIAN REVERSE. TROOPS GRADUALLY RETIRING.

div.p: Oyama reports that 2,000 Russian cavalry and infantry were encountered and defeated on the 12th inst. 30 miles to the east of Mukden. The enemy retreated northeast to- wards Hailungcheng, fighting every step. The Russians are gradually retiring along Kirin road. The positions are otherwise un- changed. (Reuter.)
Linievitch reports that the Russian cavalry raided the railway near Kaiyuan and demolished the telegraphs. (Reuter.)

div.head: THE RIVAL FLEETS. REPORT OF FIGHTING DENIED. RUSSIANS GOING NORTH.

div.p: A telegram from Manila has reached here. It states that Admiral Train, commanding the American Squadron, has received news of the arrival at Saigon yesterday morning of the Russian hospital-ship "Orel," having on board many wounded. (Reuter.)

An Imperial ordinance proclaims an imme- diate state of siege over Maku Harbour, in the Pescadores Islands, which the Japanese are believed to be using as a base. The report of fighting off Saigon is officially denied. (Reuter.)
A state of siege has been proclaimed at Mako. (Havas.)
Naval experts believoethat Rodjestvensky will pass eastward of Japan, in order to ap- proach Vladivostok from the east through the islands. (Reuter.)
(Official). The "Orel" had no wounded on board. (Reuter.)
The Russian squadron is going towards the north. (Havas.)
Count Lamsdorff has just expressed to the Scandinavian Legation his regret that Rodjest- vensky's fleet fired on the Norwegian S.S. "Aldebaran." (Reuter.)

It is stated here that the Sultan of Morocco has replied to the French Mission declaring that he has already signed an agreement with France about the Algerian boundary. The other reforms must be referred to the Powers which signed the Madrid Convention whereby he was bound. (Reuter.)

div.head: THE FISCAL FIGHT. "MODUS VIVENDI" TO BE ARRANGED.

div.p: A meeting of Tariff Reform Members of Parliament, presided over by Mr. Chamberlain, appointed a deputation, headed by Mr. Chamberlain, to wait upon Mr. Balfour with a view to arranging a "modus vivendi." It is understood that Mr. Chamberlain has decided for the present to confine his fiscal programme to the policy advocated by Mr. Balfour. The Duke of Devonshire and his supporters are regarded as irreconcilables. (Reuter.)

The new Governor-General of the Caucasus has convened representatives of all classes to confer with him with reference to judicial administrative reforms. He held out the pros- pect od the allotment of various Crown lands amongst the inhabitants. He announces that the Tsar has ordered a revision of the Arme- nian Church property question. (Reuter.)
The Council of State has validated the elections of 23 Municipal Councillors at Mar- seilles, among whom is M. Chanot, and has cancelled 13. (Havas.)
Anglo-American Nile Steamer & Hotel Company
River Transport of Good Between Alexandria & Cairo
Three Sailings a-Week.
Agents at Alexandria:
Alexandria Bonded Warehouse Co. Ld
A Council or Ministers will be held on Monday next, under the presidency of H.H. the Khedive.
H. M.'s First class Cruiser' "Diadem" sailed from Suez yesterday bound to Aden, en route to China.

div.head: The Charity Bazaar
div.p: organised by M. and Mme M. Cattaoui, for the Israelite Hospital to be built at Abbassieh, has brought in a profit. of about L.E. 200.

div.head: Attempted Murder
div.p: The Alexandria Na- tive Tribunal has sentenced Mohamed Hassan el Faleh to 5 years' hard labour for the attempted murder of a native of the Behera.

div.head: Land Purchase
div.p: We bear that MM. Rasponi and Abignente, members of the Italian Chamber of Deputies, have bought Daoud Pasha's land at Ghezireh Tebadrak for L.E. 15,000.

div.head: Execution
div.p: The first execution at Alexandria in the newly-erected execution chamber at Hadra Prison will take place shortly, when the murderer Basscouni will undergo the extreme penalty of the law.

div.head: National Bank
div.p: The Committee of the London Stock Exchange has decided to allow the following securities to be quoted in the Official List-National Bank of Egypt, fur- ther issue of 50,000 shares of £10 each, fully paid, Nes. 200,001 to 250,000.

div.head: Suez Canal
div.p: 10 vessels passed through the Canal on the 12th Inst., of which 6 were British, 1 German, 1 Dutch, 2 French. The day's receipts were frs. 324,586.42, making the total from the 1st inst. frs. 3,896,862.52.

div.head: Mariout
div.p: In the memory of the oldest inhabitants-and there are quite a number of centenarians there--this year's barley crop in the Mariout district has never been surpassed both for quantity and quality. The crops on the Khedive's estates at Mariout are exceptionally good.

div.head: Ancient Egyptian Skulls
div.p: The Oxford Reader in Egyptology, Mr. Randall MacIver, has been examining ancient Egyptian skulls with the result that he has discovered that the Englishman has half as large a negroid element in his constitution as the prehistoric Egyptian.

div.head: Egyptian Speculative Enterprise
div.p: "Spe- culative enterprise (remarks the "Financial Times" of the 4th inst.) on the part of the Egyptians themselves has been on a heavy scale,and so far the local demand for securities of all kinds shows no signs of slackening. It is to be hoped that the pace will be pre- vented from becoming too rapid."

div.head: Coal Imports.
div.p: From the 1st Jan. to 13th inst., 194,330 tons of coal were imported into Egypt. For the corresponding period of last year the quantity was 324,589 tons. This year Newcastle sent 45,082 tons, the Welsh districts 102,954, the Scotch districts 22,749, Yorkshire 13,901, and other places 6,644 tons.

div.head: Baldness a Egypt
div.p: An inscription has been discovered showing the antiquity of baldness in Egypt Teta, King of Egypt some 3,500 years b.c., has left on record the formula of a compound designed to promote the luxuriance of his mother-in-law's hair. At this distance of time it is hard to say whether he was honestly sympathetic in his efforts, or merely the ac- complice of all ages in making sport of such unhappy victims.

div.head: New Egyptian Co.
div.p: The article from the "Financier" in our issue of Wednesday last on the position and prospects of the New Egyptian Company pointed out that, whilst the nominal share capital was £500,000 and the debenture capital £100,000, only £293,879 of the former and £55,000 of the latter had been issued up to now. The debentures, however, were referred to as Four per Cents. instead of Five per Cents., so that the yield is 1 per cent. better than was made to appear.

div.head: Employes' Federations
div.p: The societies lately ,ormed will undoubtedly render the greatest services to this interesting class of workers. But the employes must themselves be the authors of their own prosperity, and they will most assuredly attain their object if they but apply themselves to acquiring the principal languages spoken in Egypt:-English, French, German, Arabic, Greek, Italian, etc. The Berlitz School, thanks to its unrivalled system, will enable them to thus attain their end ; a trial lesson will be sufficient to assure them of it. 25781-1

div.head: The National Hotel,
div.p: in Soliman Pasha- street, Cairo, which has been in course of construction for some time, is gradually nearing completion,and from what may be seen so far, is sure to be a great favorite with our visitors. The furniture has been ordered in England, and will be completely installed before the 1st November, the opening day of this new hotel. Both the dining-room and saloon will be sumptuously decorated, the latter in Louis XII. style, and will offer all the comfort and luxury money and modern appliances can supply. Mr. Chas. Bauer, the well-known proprietor of the Bristol Hotel, has agreed to take over the management of the National, and thus visitors may be certain of being properly attended to. The position of the new hotel, surrounded by mansions and villas, and in a quiet, aristocratic neighbour- hood, will greatly enhance its valou, and the big verandah, which is being constructed, is bound to be the meeting-place of many resi- dents and tourists during the next season.

div.head: THE HAHMAL'S RETURN. ESCORT ATTACKED BY BEDOUINS. A SHARP SKIRMISH.
div.p: The Emir el Hag telegraphs that the Mahmal, which left Yambo on the 4th March, has reached Medina. Between Yambo and Medina the escort and pilgrims were attacked by a band of Bedouins, who were successfully re- pulsed in a sharp skirmish. The Emir adds that details will follow by post.

Ibrahim Pasha Neghib, who has returned to Cairo from Tor, states that the enquiry which he opened as to the death of a Moor, who was supposed to have been killed and buried by his fellow pilgrims, resulted in the discovery that the Moor had died in alf apopletic fit. His friends, fearing that they might be suspected of poisoning, buried his body with- out informing the authorities.

The delegate of the Quarantine Board at the Hedjaz has sent a report on the pilgrimage from Yambo in which he says that the general health of the pilgrims has so far been good. Dysentery continues to prevail, while smallpox is easily spread among the pilgrims in general, and is not fought against at Yambo, where persons attacked by smallpox are dispersed everywhere. The delegate says that he himself noticed a case of small pox among the pilgrims with the Mahmal, and another was that of the wife of the doctor who accom- panied the Egyptian caravan on behalf of the Sanitary Administration.
Eight thousand pilgrims are ready to leave for Tor, five thousand of whom are Egyptian. Their condition of health is satisfactory.

div.head: THURSDAY'S RAILWAY ACCIDENT.
div.p: The child to whom the unfortunate accident happened on the railway line which we re- counted in our issue of yesterday, is the five- year-old daughter of M. Debbane, Brazilian Consul-General. The injuries which she sustained are more serious than was at first believed, and as yet she cannot unfortunately be pro- nounced out of danger. It appears that the child was not knocked out of the carriage, but feel out owing to the door not being properly fastened.

Mme Debbane, who was in the carriage with her daughter, driven to despair, was only pre- vented from throwing herself on the line, in a wild desire to save her daughter, by a gentleman who happened to be in her company.

On the train being stopped, Prince Mohamed Ibrahim, Mohamed Bey Said, and Mohamed Bey Rassehm joined the other passengers in the search for the girl and gave every assistance in their power. The child had meantime been picked up by a camel-driver, who brought her to Galioub station, where first aid was admi- nistred.
The train was backed to Galioub and the child was then taken on and brought to Alexandria, where she now lies in a dangerous condition at her father's residence.

div.head: NEW TRAMWAY CONCESSION.
div.p: The Ministry of Public Works has given its approval to the scheme proposed by Boghos Pasha Nubar and M. Empain for the construc- tion of a new tramway to run along the Ismailieh Canal to the desert near Abbas- sieh. The terms of the concession are now being studied.

div.head: ABOUKIR COMPANY.
div.p: We understand that at the ordinary meeting of the Aboukir Company, Limited, to be held in London next week, the directors will propose a dividend for the year 1904 of 7 % on the ordinary shares, and also 7 % on the deferred shares. The ordinary shares in January received a dividend of 11 % in payment of balance of arrears of their 7 % cumulative dividend.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: His Highness passed the day at Montazah Palace yesterday. He leaves for Cairo this evening, after opening the Horticultural Show at San Stefano.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL YACHT CLUB.
div.p: The opening regatta of the season will be held on Wednesday afternoon next, 19th inst. Members are requested to send in the entries for their boatS at onCe to the honorary secre- tary. The handicap Will be published in Tuesday afternoon's "Gazette," as usual. It has been decided to give the prizes every four regattas instead of every three, the points to connt the same as last year.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The Moss liner "Moeris" arrived this morning from Liverpool, via Oran and Malta, with passengers and mails.

div.head:
THE COLDEN GROSS LINE.
FOR CARDIFF AND BRISTOL DIRECT.
div.p: The fast steamer "Venedotian" will arrive on or about the 17th April and will have room for about 1,400 tons of cargo.
For Freight and references, please apply to Alick Nimnim & Son,
Marina, Alexandria.

div.head: OPENING OF RACING SEASON. A. S. C. SKYE MEETING.
div.p: The racing season at Alexandria opened yesterday with the Alexandria Sporting Club's April Skye Meeting. Notwithstanding the very fine weather which prevailed, there was not a very large turn out of the public, especially in the early part of the meeting, when the grand stand bore a somewhat bare appearance. Later, however, a number of ladies graced the enclosure with their pre- sence, and more animation prevailed. In the racing the only feature of interest was the five successive wins brought about by Khalil Pasha Khayat's stable, and the owner is to be congratulated on his signal success. Jenkins rode four of the five winning mounts, acquitting himself very creditably. Though there were very good fields the finishes did not afford any excitement, with the exceptin of the Pony Stakes, which was the closest. The prettiest race of the day was the one for the Ladies' Bracelet. There were no less than 16 starters, and all were riding coming up the straight. Pari Mutual yielded good returns, the favorites not coming up to anticipations. The following are the results of the various events, the enjoyment of which was considerably enhanced by the playing of the R. Berks. Band :—

NOVICES' RACE of P.T. 2,500, viz : P.T. 2,000 to winner and P.T. 500 to 2nd horse. For Arabs that have never run in a race of any description, Amateur races and Gymkhanas excepted. Horses 10.7, Galloways 10.3 and ponies 10.0. Distance 5 furlongs.

Khalil Pasha Khayat's c.a.p. little Korosko, 10.0. Jenkins. 1 Mr. A. J. Sursock's g.a.p. Flying Dutchman, 10.7. Stillwell. 2 Mr. A. J. Sursock's br.ap. Nigri, 10.3. Elias.3 Ibrahim Bey Cherifs g.a.h. Saclavie, 10.8. Ka- mel Effendi. 0 Mr. M. Tueni's ch.a.h. Ajax, 10.7. Mr. G. H. Barker. 0 Mr. Tueni's g.a.p. Hercule, 10.0. Matthews. 0 Saleh Bey Yaghen's g.a.h. Waasal, 10.7. Sha- kir. 0 Mr. K. Karam's g.a.p. Bayard, 10.0. Michaeli- des, Jun. 0 Mr J. Hoyami's g.a.h. Tonnerre, 10.7. Owner. 0 Mr. E. Bastros' g.a.h. Moulk, 10.7. Fenwick. 0 Khalil Pasha Khayat's b.a.h. Zariff III. 10.7. Whiteside. 0 Moh. Pasha Chehim's g.a.p. Derwish, 10.0. Mr. A. J. Michaelides. 0
Despatched to a good start, little Korosko led nearly all the way and won easily by two lengths. A length separated 2nd and 3rd. Time, 1.9.

Totalisator paid P.T. 58 on winner and P.T. 27, 340, and 43 for places. MAIDEN PONY PLATE of P.T. 2,500, viz: P.T. 2,000 to winner and P.T. 500 to 2nd horse. For Maiden Arab ponies. Weight for age and inches. Distance 1 mile.

Khalil Pasha Khayat's g.a.p. Au Revoir, 10.10. Jenkins. 1 Khalil Pasha Khayat's g.a.p. Zeidan, 9.10. Whiteside. 2 Messrs. W. B. Rees and G. H. Barker's g.a.p. India, 9.10. Mr. G. H. Barker. 3 Mohsen Pasha's g.a.p. Taib, 10.3. Mikhali. 0 Messrs. W. B. Rees and G. H. Barker's b.a.p. Firefly, 10.7. Mr Ramsay. 0 Mr. E. Karam's g.a.p. Nimrod, 9.10. Mi- chaelides, Jun. 0 Saleh Bey Yaghen's b.ap. Spectre, 10.8. Bonser. 0 Ibrahim Bey Cherifs g.a.p. Sattam, lO.5 Kamel Effendi. 0 Ishak Bey Hussein and Hassan Bey Kheir el Din's c.a.p. Rais, 10.7. Stillwell. 0

A good start, all keeping well together till they entered the cutting, when Au Revoir took up the lead, followed by Taib, and Spectre. In the straight, Zeidan came to the front but could not reach Au Revoir, who won easily by about two lengths, India being a bad third. Time, 1.53 1/2.
Totalisator paid P.T. 36 on winner, and P.T. 26, 41, and 43 for places.
TRIAL PLATE of P.T. 2,500, viz : P.T. 2,000 to winner and P.T. 500 to 2nd horse. For Maiden Arabs. Weight for age. Distance 6 furlongs.

Khalil Pasha Khayat's c.a.p. Klondyke, 10.5. Jenkins. 1 Ishak Bey Hussein's ch.a.h. El Tahawi, 10.7. Stillwell. 2 Mr. M. Tueni's b.a.h. Caprice, 10.7. Matthews. 3 Mohsen Pasha b.a.h. Gogo, 10.7. Mikhali. 0 Moharrem Pasha Chehim's g.a.h. Jupiter, 10.6. Mr. A. J. Michaelides. 0 Khalil Pasha Khayat's g.a.p. Lonlou, 10.6. Whiteside 0 Capt. G. B. Byrne's g.a.h. Chinaman, 10.7. Moursi. 0 Messrs. W. B. Rees and G. H. Barker's b.a.h. Ion, 10.7. Mr. G. H. Barker. 0 Ishak Bey Hussein's g.a.h. Sir Visto, 10.8. Fenwick. 0
Klondyke made most of the running and won fairly easily by a length, the others being close up. Time, 1.22 1/2.
Totalisator paid P.T. 78 on winner, and P.T. 27, 28, and 45 for places.
PONY STAKES of P.T. 2,500. 2nd horse to receive P.T. 500 out of the Stakes. For ' Arab ponies. Weight for age and inches with penalties. Distance 6 furlongs.

Khalil Pasha Khayat's g.ap. Kawkab, 9.6. Jenkins. 1 Ishak Bey Hussein and Haasan Bey Kheir el Din's b.a.p. Faik, 9.7. Stillwell 2 Messrs. W. B. Rees and G. H. Barkers g.a.p. Vandal 10.0. Mr. G. H. Barker. 3 Ibrahim Bey Cherif's g.a.p. Amour, 9.3. Aly Hawass. 0 Ibrahim Bey Cherifs g.a.p. Sattam. 9.6. Eliseo. 0 Moharrem Pasha Chehim's g.a.p. Mamdouh, 9.2. Mr. A. J. Michaelides. 0 Khalil Pasha Khayat's c.a.p. Suleik, 9.6. White- side. 0

Amour got the best of a headstart, Suleik being left at the post. Amour was soon joined in the lead by Sattan, but on coming into the straight both horses fell back and the rest was a close race between Kawkab and Faik, the former winning by a length. Time, 1.25.
Totalizator paid P.T. 99 on winner, and P.T. 30,59, and 90 for places.

LADIES BRACELET of P.T. 2,000 presented by the Alexandria an Ramleh Railway Company, viz: P.T. 1,000 to the nominator of the winner and P.T. 1,000 to the owner together with P.T. 500 added to go to 2nd horse. For Arabs that have never won a race except Gymkhanas. To be nominate by ladies. Horses 11.7, Ponies 10.11. Distance 6 furlongs.

Khalil Pasha Khayat's g.a.h. Sinounou, 11.7. Whiteside. 1 Mr. H. Eisler's g.a.h. Temsah, 10.11 Elias. 2 Mr. M. Tueni's g.a.h. Faineant, 11.7 Mr. G. H. Barker. 3 Mr. A. J. Sursock's g.a.h. Flying Dutchman, 11.7. stillwell. 0 Khalil Pasha Khayat's c.a.p. Doughan, 10.11. Jenkins. 0 Mr. E. Bustros' g.a.h. Numir, 10.11. Fenwick. 0 Moharrem Pasha Chehim's g.a.h. Jupiter, 11.7. Mr. A.J. Michaelidis. 0 Moh. Pasha Cdhehim;s g.a.p. Dervish, 10.11. 0 Mr. M. Tueni's g.a.p. Hercule, 10.11. Matthews. 0 Mr. E. Karam's' g.a.h. Boheme, 11.7. Michaeli- des Jun. 0 Sales Bey Yaghen's g.a.h. Vassal, 11.7. Shakir. 0 Sales Bey Yaghen's b.a.p. Spectre, 10.11 Bonser. 0 Ibrahim Bey Cherif's g.a.h. Soulferino, 10.11. Eliseo. 0 Ibrahim Bey Cherif's g.a.h. Azize, 11.7. Aly Hawass. 0 Ibrahim Bey Cherif's g.a.h. Saclavie, 11.7. Kamel Effendi. 0

This was a very pretty race. The big field were despatched to a good start, all the horses keeping together in a cluster until entering the straight, when Temsah was seen to have gained slightly the advantage. In the straight Sinounou came through his horses and shot ahead, Temsah at his heels. He was never overtaken, however, and won by a couple of lengths. Nearing the post, Faineant came with a rush and almost wrested 2nd place from Temsah, who only got it by a head. Time, 1.24.
Totalisator paid P.T. 247 on winner, and P.T. 75, 57, and 155 for places.
APRIL PLATE of P.T. 2,500. 2nd horse to receive P.T. 500 out of the Stakes. For Arabs. Weight for age with penalties. Distance round the course.

Mr. A. J. Sursook's g.a h. Boule de Neige, 9.4. Elias. 1 Mr. P. W. Stout's g.a.h. Showman, 9.7. Whiteside. 2 Khalil Pasha Khayat's g.a.p. Au Revoir, 9.7. Jenkins. 3 Mr. Teuni's b.a.p. Caprice, 9.7. Matthews. 0 Isak Bey Hussein's and hassan Bey Kheir el Din's ch.a.p. Rais, 9.7. Stillwell. 0 Ibrahim Bey Cherif's g.a.h. Royalist, 9.7. Kamel Effendi. 0 Mr. E. Karam's ch.a.h. Coeur de Lion, 9.7. Michaelides, Jun. 0 Messrs. W. B. Rees and G. H.Barker's ch.a.h. Shari, 9.7, Mr. G. H. Barker. 0

The horses got away to a good start, Mash- kour and Coeur de Lion leading. When reaching the mile post, Coeur de Lion still maintained the premier position, with Royalist in close attendance. On entering the cutting Boule de Neige challenged the leader and was first into the straight, where all were riding. Coeur de Lion was now done with and although Au Revoir at one time looked like winning, Boule de Neige got first past the post by barely a length, Au Revoir being some distance behind Shewiman. Time, 2.35.
Totalisator paid P.T. 48 on winner, and P.T. 27, 76, and 36 for places.

div.head: PASSENGER LISTS.
ARRIVALS.
div.p: Per Moss S.S. "Moeris" arrived to-day from Liverpool :-
Mr. H.B. Johnston, Pte W. Salt, Pte W. Skillett, and 4 deck passengers.
Lo paquobot "Salaria" des Messageries Ma- ritimes parti hier pour Marseille avait a bord.

M. et Mme Beyram Bey et Mustafa Bayram Bey, M. et Mme Barbier, M. et Mme Gutmann, M. Specht, Mme. Hatter, M. le Dr Kenneth Scott, Mme Kenneth Scott, Mme H. S. Gaze, Mlle. Rich, M. et Mme G. Watson, M. le Dentu, M. de Heredia, M. et Mme J. L. Baird, Cap. Cave, Mme. Bernard, M. Appert, Mme J. Roche, Mlle. Teed, M. Bonhomme, M. Offentranger, M. Mowat, M. Paul Honal, M. Benoit, Mme. Favre, Clogstooun, M. et Mme Coutant, M. Emile Claville, M. H. Mathews, Mme Susznna Valmont, M. J. Rapaport, Madame Fillion, Madame Royet, M. Thomas, Mrs. G. R. et A. Huri et sa dame, Mlle Kheror, Mme. Myrthes, Mme Dorey, M. Constantopoulo, Mlle Florence Mellor, M. Schehade, M. Lambert, M. Tennant, M. Halek Ismail, Miss Bourguer, M. Bedouin, M. Affrentangen, M Tarpinian, M. Essely, M.Copping, Mme. Kamleh, M. Darcier, M. et Mme Garnier, M. A. I. Larrat, M. Vallet, M. Oback, M. et Mme Chiess, Mlle. Hurully, Mme. Besson, M. Fritz, M. Moray.

div.head: TYROL.
div.p: Weissentein Castle 3410 ft. First-class private hotel near Windisch Matroi ; Station, Liens (reached from Venice or Trieate). Good mountaineering centre. Tennis. Fishing, best June and September. Prospectuses and Pho- to graphs, "Egyptian Gazette" office, Cairo.

div.head: CARLTON HOTEL
div.p: Bulkeley, Ramleh.
Ten minutes from Alexandria. First-Class in every respect Very moderate charges. Bulkeley is the fashionable English quarter. Visitors fron Cairo alight at Sidi Gaber Station.
G. AQUILINA, Proprieter.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: Prince Mohamed Aly, brother of the Khedive, arrived at Constantinople on Monday last. His Highness went straight to the Imperial Palace, and afterward, to the Yali of the Khedivah Mother at Bebek, where he is at present residing.
Prince Aziz Pasha Hassen and Zeky Pasha arrived at Alexandria from Cairo last evening.
Abdul Halim Pasha Assem, Director-General of the Wakfs Administration, has left for Cairo.
M. de la Bouliniere, French Diplomatic Agent, arrived from Cairo yesterday. He is staying with M. P. Girard, French Consul at Alexandria.
Councillor A. C. Cumbo leaves today for Brindisi by the "Semiramis." He intends to spend the Easter holidays at Rome with his family and will be back in Alexandria in three weeks.
The marriage arranged between Miss Mary Prior and Mr. William H. E. Quintana will take place at St. Catherine's Cathedral Alexandria, on Monday, 24th inst., at 2 p.m.

We regret to announce the death, which took place at Alexandria yesterday, of M. Gregoire Mistrovachi. The funeral of deceased, who was a chevalier of the Order of Francis- Joseph, took place this morning, at the Greek Orthodox cemetery,
We have received P.T. 50 from Mme. Vve. H. Gantse and a like amount from Mr. E. C. Manuk, for the St. Vincent de Paul charity, in memory of the late M. Mistrovachi.

div.head: ALL SAINTS' CHURCH, CAIRO.
div.p: On Monday, Tueday, Wednesday, and Thurs- day, April 17th to 20th the Services will be as follows:— 8.30 a.m. Holy Communion. 10.30 " Morning prayer. 6.30 p.m. Evensong and Address.
On Good Friday 8.30 a.m. Ante-Communion. 10.30 „ Morning Prayer and Sermon. 2.— p.m. One hour Service. 6.- " Evening Prayer and Sermon.
On Easter Eve Holy Communion 8.30 a.m. Morning Prayer 10.30 „
On EASTER DAY Holy Communion 6.30 a.m. 7.30 a.m. 8.30 a.m. and after Morning Service. Other Servicee as on Sundays.
On Easter Monday and Tuesday Holy Communion 8.30 a.m.
Offertory on Good Friday will be devoted to the Jerusalem and the East Mission Fund.

div.head: ST. MARK'S, ALEXANDRIA. HOLY WEEK.
div.p: Monday to Thursday inclusive 8 a.m. Holy Communion. 11 a.m. Morning Prayer and Address. 5.30 p.m. Evening Prayer and Address.
Good Friday. 8 am. Ante-Communion Service. 11 a.m. Morning Player, Litany, and Sermon. 6.15 p.m. Evening Prayer and Address.
Easter Eve. 8 a.m. Ante-Communion Service
EASTER DAY. Three Celebrations of the Holy Com- munion, 7 a.m. 8 a.m. and Noon. 11 a.m. Matins and Sermon. 6.15 a.m. Evensong and Sermon.

div.head: ALL SAINTS' RAMLEH. HOLY WEEK.
div.p: Monday to Thursday inclusive: 8 a.m. Holy Communion. 6 p.m. Evening Prayer and Address.
Good Friday. 8 a.m. Ante-Communion Service. 11 a.m. Morning Prayer, Litany, and Sermon. 6.30 p.m. Evening Prayer and Address.
EASTER DAY. The Holy Communion will be celebrated at 7.30 a.m., 8.30 am. and at noon, in addition to the usual services at 11 am. 3.30 p.m. and 6.30. p.m.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
(Auiourd'hui a midi et demie)
div.p: Le marche en general se maintient dans les positions acquises. Certaines valeurs accusent meme une hausse notable ; entre autres, la Daira et la Crown Brewery. Quant aux transac- tions, elles ont ete assez nombreuses, en parti- culier en Daira et en Salt and Soda.
La Daira debute a 27 3/8, et atteint 28 pour cloturer achetersn a 27 15/16 avec tendance marquee a la hausse.
De 210 la Crown Brewery passe en raison d'une forte demands a 220, prix anquel elle cloture acheteurs.
De 38/8 al'ouverture la Salt and Soda a'eleve graduellement a 39/83 en cloture avec beau- coup d'affaires.
Il y a du mieux aussi en Investment a 2 3/16, en Oasis a 1 838 et an Privileglees Tram- ways a 147 1/2.
Par contre la Nungovich est plus fiable a 10 1/4 l'Anglo American Nile a 5 13/16, la Delta Light a 14 1/8 et la Ramleh Railway a 8 3/16.

div.head: "INVESTMENTS.”
div.p:
"Investments” introduces, in an entirely original manner, new and important methods for the employment of and the means of obtaining capital. Among the
SPECIALLY CONTRIBUTED ARTICLES
are "Stock Markets and How to Profit by Them”; "Theory of Successful Speculation”; "How to start an Account” ; "The Advantages of 'Call Options'”; "Contangoing Mining and Industrial Securities” ; "How to Invest in Mines”; "American Rails, with Points for Operators in Yankees”; "The Purchase of Investment Securities by Instalments” ; "General Principles for Investors” ; "Rules for Investors in Mines”; "General Principles for Speculators”; "Stock Exchange Terms,” being a glossary for Market Operators; "Stock Exchange Parlance”; "Insurance, as a Means of Making, Raising, and Saving Money,” and "Colonial Building Land: Its Great Possibilities.”
"Investments” (148 pages) sent Post Free on mentioning "Egyptian Gazette.”
LONDON & PARIS EXCHANGE LIMITED, GENERAL BANKERS. BASILDON HOUSE, BANK, LONDON, E.C.

div.head: EASTERN TELEGRAPH CO. LTD.
div.p: AVERAGE TIME occupied in transmission of Egyptian telegrams from England to Alexandria on Tuesday, 11th July, 1905.
OUTWARDS.
Between the hours of 10 a.m. and 6 p.m. (Cairo time)

div.head: TRAMWAYS D'ALEXANDRIE
div.p: (SOCIÉTÉ ANONYME)

Les Actionnaires des Tramways d'Alexandrie, Société Anonyme, sont convoqués en Assem- blée Générale le mercredi 3 Mai prochain, à 2 heures de relevée, au siège social à Bruxelles, 108, Rue Royale, pour délibérer sur le suivant ORDRE DU JOUR:
1° Rapport du Conseil d'administration et des Commissaires.
2° Approbation du Bilan ainsi que du compte Profits et Pertes de l'exercice au 31 Dé- cembre 1904 et fixation du dividende." 3° Election des Commissaires pour l'exercice 1905.
4° Tirage de 128 obligations.
Messieurs les Actionnaires, pour être admis à l'Assemblée, doivent se conformer à l'article 28 des Statuts.
Les dépôts d'actions sont reçus
A Bruxelles chez Messieurs Balser et Cie, 7 rue d'Arenberg au plus tard le 28 Avril cou- rant au matin ;

A Alexandrie: à la Banque Impériale Otto- mane, à la National Bank of Egypt, au Crédit Lyonnais, à la Bank of Egypt Ltd., à l'Anglo- Egyptian Bank Ltd., et à la Banque d'Athènes au plus tard le 20 Avril courant.
Le Président du Conseil d'Administration 25740-2*-2 J. Lumbroso.

div.head: SOCIETE ANONYME
div.p: Agricole et Industrielle d'Egypte
AVIS
MM. les Actionnaires sont convoqués en Assemblée Générale Ordinaire le samedi 6 Mai 1905 à 4 1/2 h. p.m. au Siège Social au Caire.
ORDRE DU JOUR :
1. Lecture du rapport du Conseil d'Admi- nistration sur les affaires de la Société. 2. Lecture du rapport des Commissaires. 3. Approbation des comptes et fixation du dividende pour l'année 1904.
4. Renouvellement partiel du Conseil d'Ad- ministration et du Collège des Commissai- res. (Art. 11 et 27 des Statuts).
Tout porteur d'actions a le droit d'assister à l'Assemblée Générale, mais conformément à l'Art. 31 des Statuts, les actions devront être déposées avant le 21 Avril 1905.
EN EGYPTE : Au Siège Social au Caire.
à l'Anglo Egyptian Bank Ld au Crédit Lyonnais.
à la Banque Imp. Ottoman à la Banque of Egypt Ld.
EN BELGIQUE: à la Banque d'Anvers à
Anvers et chez MM. les Administrateurs de la So
giété,

div.head: SOCIETE FONCIERE D'EGYPTE
div.p: AVIS AUX ACTIONNAIRES
Dans sa séance du 10 Avril 1905, l'Assem- blée Générale Ordinaire a décidé la distribution de Une Livre Sterling (P.T. 97 20/40) par action à titre de dividende pour l'Exercice 1904.
Le paiement sera effectué à partir du 17 Avril 1905 et contre remise du coupon No. 6 au et
à Alexandrie} à la National Bank of Egypt.
L'Administrateur-Délégué Joseph A. Cattaui Bey

div.head: National Bank of Egypt.
div.p: AVIS

Le Conseil d'Administration de la National Bank of Egypt a l'honneur de porter à la con- naissance des intéressés que l'Assemblée Géné rale Ordinaire des Actionnaires réunie le Lundi 20 Mars, 1905, au Siège Social, au Caire, a fixé à 14 shellings le montant du dividende à payer par action pour l'exercice clos le 31 Décembre 1904. Ce dividende est payable contre remise du coupon No. 5 à partir du 23 Mars 1905, au Siège Social de la Banque, au Caire, à sa Suc- cursale à Alexandrie, dans ses Agences des Provinces et à son Agence de Londres 4 & 5, King William Street.. 25628-8*-5

div.head: BRASSERIE DES PYRAMIDES (EX CROWN BREWERY OF CAIRO)
div.p: SOCIÉTÉ ANONYME

Siege Social, 106 Rue Royale Bruxelles. Le Conseil d'Administration a l'honneur de porter à la connaissance de Messieurs les Ac- tionnaires que l'Assemblée Générale Ordinaire aura lieu à Bruxelles le Mercredi 3 Mai 1905, à 3 heures de l'après-midi, Rue du Marais,55.- ORDRE DU JOUR
1°/ Rapports du Conseil d'Administration et du Collège des Commissaires sur les exer- cices 1903-1904.-
2°/ Approbation des Bilans et du Compte des Profits et Pertes des exercices 1903-1904.- 3° Nomination d'Administrateurs et d'un Commissaire au Caire.-

Pour être admis à l'assemblée, Messieurs les Actionnaires auront à se conformer à l'article 32 des statuts. Les actions doivent être dépo- sées à Bruxelles, à la Banque Balser & Co. En Egypte, dans l'un des établissements financiers ci-après nommés: Banque Impériale Ottomane, Bank of Egypt, Anglo Egyptian Bank Ltd., National Bank of Egypt, Crédit Lyonnais, Banque d'Athènes et Cassa di Sconto e di Risparmio.
Le Président du Conseil (Signé), J. G. CHAKOUR.

div.head: The Egyptian Delta Land & Investment Company Limited
div.p: PROPOSED ISSUE OF 100,000) FURTHER SHARES OF £1 EACH RANKING AS OF ONE CLASS WITH THE ORIGINAL £100,000 OF SHARE CAPITAL.

The Board of Directors of the above Com- pany are proposing to offer the above Shares pro rata to those existing Proprietors who are known to the Company and who have paid up cheir present holding in full, or do so at the time of accepting this offer, that is to say, one new Share for every Share already held, at the price of £2 per Share. In order that a form of offer with full particulars duly filled in and orm of acceptance attached may be issued to holders of Share Warrants to bearer, those older of Warrants who wish to participate are hereby notified that they must exhibit their Warrants for endorsement at the National Bank of Egypt, Cairo, Alexandria, or 4 & 5, King William Street, London, EC.

Daposits must be made in banking hours between the 12th April and the 22nd April, 1905 (both dates inclusive) when the form of ffer above referred to with form of acceptance ttached will be issued to the Depositor. Forms of Acceptance will be posted direct Trom the London Office of the Company to the Registered Proprietors on Tuesday the 11th April. 25769-6.3

div.head: SUDAN GOVERNMENT.
div.p: TENDERS are called for by the Steamers and Boats Department Sudan Government for the supply of food, wine and spirits, etc., on the Sudan Government Express and Post Steamers running between Shallal and Halfa and vice
versa.

The conditions under which the contract will be given can be seen at the following offices: Financial Secretary Sudan Govern- ment Cairo, Assistant Director Steamers and Boats Assouan and the Director of Steamers and Boats Khartoum North.
Tenders are to be sent to the Director Steamers and Boats Khartoum North and must be in his Office not later than April 16th, 1905. A statement showing experience is to accompany tender.
The contract will be for one year ending 17th May 1906.
The Department of Steamers and Boats does not bind itself to accept the lowest or any tender.

div.head: STOCKS AND SHARES
div.p: Furnished by Reid & Bernard 10, St. Marks Buildings, Alexandria, and Sharia Kasr-el-Nil, Cairo, who undertake the sale and purchase of Stocks and Shares, on the local Bourse and also on the London Stock Exchange.

div.head: Cloture de la Bourse Khediviale
div.p: CONTRATS
Cours de l'Association des Courtiers en Marchand. 6h. p.m.
REMARQUES
Coton.-Nouvelle récolte: L'activité a fait défaut, mais la cote est ferme quoique n'ayant pas suivi la hausse du mai.

Récolte actuelle: Marché animé dans l'après- midi et mai en hausse ultérieure. On dit que les haussiers sont décidés à faire une nouvelle tentative contre le découvert de mai. Le juillet a fini en déport de 1/2 talari. Dans la matinée prix plus haut pour mai tal. 13 21/32 à 11/16; plus bas pour mai 13 7/16 à Dans l'après-midi prix plus haut pour mai 13 25/32 à-/-; plus ba pour mai 13 11/16 à ——. N.B.-Les autres livraisons avec report irréguliers.
Au moment de la clôture les nouvelle étaient les suivantes :
Liverpool, coton égyptien disponible. Bearrés Même cours. Fut. mai: 6 40/64
Liverpool: coton américain: Futurs mai
juin: 4.09. Futurs oot.-nov. : 4.15
ont pas moins avancé.
New-York: cot, amér. : Futurs mai: 7.51
Graines de coton.-Nouvelle récolte: Quoi que les affaires aient été rares, les cours n'en
Récolte actuelle: La hausse de la journée a été assez marquée et elle a été la conséquence M du réveil de la spéculation sur l'article.

Dans la matinée prix plus haut pour avril P.T. 54 15/40 à-/-; plus bas pour avril P.T. 53 20/40 à-- Dans l'après-midi, prix plus haut pour avril P.T. 54 20/40 à -/-; plus bas pour avril P.T. 54 15/40 à
N.B.-Les autres livraisons avec reports irréguliers.
Feves-Saidi.-Nouvelle récolte: Il y a eu quelques transactions sur l'article, ce qui nous a valu pour aujourd'hui une hausse d'une piastre environ.

div.head: CONTRATS, (11h.55 a.m.)
div.p: Cours de la Bourse de Minet-el-Bassal
REMARQUES
Cotons: Nouvelle récolte.—Le novembre a ouvert à 14 15/16 sous l'impression de la clôture d'Amérique et ne tarde même pas à fléchir à 14 7/8, mais il se raffermit de nouveau. Affaires claisemées.
Récolte actuelle. —Juillet a débuté à 14 5/16 et reste soutenu. Marché peu animé.
Grains de coton: Nouvelle récolte.— Sans affaires importante; quand même les cours sont bien tenus.
Récolte actuelle.—Juillet a obtenu P.T. 58 ¾ à l'ouverture.
Fèves-Saidi: Nouvelle récolte.—Marché nul.
